Award.AwardTitle: Metal Coordination Compounds as Reporters for Biological NO
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nitric oxide (NO) is an important molecule that controls many biological processes including smooth muscle dilation in the heart and other organs, neurotransmission, and functioning of the immune system. Through this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms B Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Stephen J. Lippard from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology will investigate the chemistry of nitric oxide with transition metal complexes that can be incorporated into novel, peptide-based, platforms for its detection as a signaling agent in biology. This project investigates these roles through the preparation and application of bright, light-emitting molecules based on transition metal chemistry to track the generation and translocation of nitric oxide to its biological targets. Several of these targets include transition metals centers, and the chemistry by which they respond to NO is another subject of investigation. By directing the sensors to specific cellular locales, such as the cell membrane or organelles like the mitochondrion, spatiotemporal information about NO as a signal transduction molecule can be obtained by fluorescence microscopic studies. Reactive species derived from NO, specifically HNO (nitroxyl) and HSNO (nitrosothiol), will also be investigated. Through chemistry, the probes will be made selective for NO, HNO, or HSNO, kinetically tuned for rapid turn-on, ratiometric to allow for quantitation, reversible, and able to emit at low energies to minimize unwanted background.

The chemical dynamics and mechanisms discovered during the design and implementation of the sensors may have parallels in living systems and thereby enrich our knowledge of how transition metal centers respond to nitric oxide and its derivatives. Peptides provide an excellent platform for incorporating units to localize the sensors to subcellular locales, a great advantage for studying functions in live cells and tissue slices. Applications ranging from the design of antibiotics to the determination of the roles of nitric oxide in sensory perception can be envisioned. These projects will continue the training of young scientists in chemistry. Graduate and postdoctoral researchers on the project are also mentors to undergraduate research opportunity participants (UROPs) at MIT. These scientists are encouraged to communicate their work both orally and in writing. Many subsequently assume key positions in academic or industrial organizations and some are active in outreach programs at schools in the local communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metal Coordination Compounds as Reporters for Biological NO

Reporting Period: 09/01/2013 to 02/29/2016

Nitric oxide (NO) is a gaseous molecule that regulates a variety of processes in the human circulatory, immune, and nervous systems. Nitroxyl (HNO), the reduced and protonated form of NO, is emerging as a new species endowed with unique biochemical properties. Whether and how HNO is generated in the body are still subjects of debate. The ability to distinguish NO from HNO is therefore critical for elucidating the physiological and pathological functions of these two chemically distinct agents.

Transition metal ions participate in many of pathways by which NO is produced and exerts its actions in biology. This project explored the chemistry underlying these transformations, with two major research objectives in mind. First, we aimed to establish the mechanisms by which metalloproteins respond to NO through studies of nitric oxide reactivity with site-differentiated iron-sulfur clusters, non-sulfur metal complexes, and zinc thiolates. Important results of this research are: (i) the isolation and characterization of the nitrosation products of synthetic iron-sulfur clusters, (ii) the development of bis(imidazole) metal complexes for rapid colorimetric detection of NO, (iii) modeling the coordination environment of nitric oxide reductase enzymes with diiron complexes, (iv) identifying the requirement for zinc ions to be removed from S-nitrosothiols in order to maintain physiological reversibility of the S-nitrosation reaction, and (v) discovery of a rare example of reversible NO binding to a non-heme iron complex. Second, we designed and applied light-emitting metal-based probes to track the generation and distribution of NO and HNO in living organisms. To achieve deeper tissue penetration and high spatiotemporal resolution for biological imaging, we explored novel fluorescent and metal-binding moieties and produced sensors for NO and HNO that are brighter, faster, redder, and more selective. Another important outcome of our research was the application of biocompatible solid-phase approaches to prepare, functionalize, and program sensors with less synthetic effort. The innovative, modular solid-phase method developed under this project can be employed to generate families of fluorescent probes. Science revealed by our metal-based compounds provided answers to important biological questions and engendered several national and international collaborations. The successful implementation of our lysine-based nitroxyl sensor confirmed a proposed biosynthetic pathway to HNO. Our parent sensor for nitroxyl has been pivotal in revealing the biochemistry of HNO and HSNO, the smallest S-nitrosothiol. Finally, our improved NO sensors were used to: (i) visualize nitric oxide in the vasculature, (ii) establish a relation between nitrosative stress and α-synuclein toxicity in Parkinson’s disease, and (iii) define the role of calcium in peroxide-dependent cardiac signaling pathways. Several of our probes are already commercially available.

This project has unveiled physiological and pathological actions of NO and HNO, with broad impacts on chemistry, biology, neuroscience, and medicine. Our research group displays gender and ethnic diversity and actively supports mentoring and training of underrepresented minorities in science at undergraduate, graduate, and postgraduate levels. Outreach activities funded by this project include worldwide workshops and lectures that instill excitement for chemistry. The PI has been a guest on the NPR program Science Friday.
